body.value: Orosius (1.2.104)) describes the Balearic islands (Maiorca and Minorca) as having two corresponding cities, Maiorca having the Spanish city of Tarragona to its north. Here it appears that the city has transferred its name to the island. Orosius: Insulae Baleares duae sunt, maior et minor, quibus insunt bina oppida, maior Tarraconam Hispaniae ciuitatem, minor Barcilonam septentrionem uersus contra se habent. [There are two Balearic islands, Maiorca and Minorca, with two fortified towns: on Maiorca - the city of Spanish Tarragona, on Minorca
Some identify the Gorgades with the Cape Verde Islands.
The Expositio Mappa Mundi cites Solinus (19:6): a litere Scytharum in insulam Abalciam triduo navigari... [from the coast of Scythia to the island of Albatia [it takes] three days to sail...]
Solinus (16.1) notes that Hyperboreans are a blessed people: De Hyperboreis rem loquemur. Incolunt pone Pterophoron, quem ultra aquilonem accipimus iacere. Gens beatissima.
A people who live in extreme north Asia

The inscription's second letter remains uncertain, allowing for two interpretations of this place name. Miller (vol. 3, 39) suggests Archaia [Arcadia]. Although both Achaia and Arcadia can be found in the same geographical location, there is no instance of Arcadia being noted without Achaia. There are however multiple instances of Achaia being noted without Arcadia. In fact, the Hidgen Royal is the only map that mentions Arcadia, and that is alongside Achaia.

The editors here consider Achaea to be the most likely translation, but the presence of the second letter d remains unexplained.
Or perhaps the city of Sitha.
Miller (vol. 3, 39) notes that he Ebstorf map has an analogue: Wolkan, or Volga River. Chekin (141-142) suggests "the left tributary of the Danube."

Only the first three characters of this inscription are legible. The inscription could either be severely abbreviated, or the remaining characters may have been damaged by the corrosive green pigment of the nearby sea.

Miller (vol. 3, 39) suggests that the first three letters are Bor- for Bordigala/Burdigala, or Bordeaux. The Bri- reading proposed here posits that these letters strongly resemble the Bri- found at the beginning of the Britannia inscription, suggesting a reading of Britanny rather than Bordeaux. See similar inscriptions on several of the Higden maps as potential analogues.
The -c- in this inscription is far more reminiscent of an -e-, but the word in its entirety is undoubtedly meant to represent Barcelona.
This inscription has an analogue in the Hereford Map, Mons Sueuus.
The legendary Rhiphaean mountains formed a natural boundary between Asia and Europe. They are sometimes identified with the modern-day Ural mountain range in Russia.
Associated with illustration of ark on the peak of Mount Ararat.

Miller (vol. 3, 40) transcribes this annotation as Contolis and notes that it does not appear in any other map. He suggests a corruption perhaps of the Araxes River, which originates in the Armenian Mountains. Hugh of Saint-Victor (Gautier Dalché, 144) also mentions the Araxes River in Armenia.The Psalter Map, however, displays both an upper and lower branch of this river; Fluuius Cintilis may refer to the upper branch, the modern-day Kura River (Cyrus in ancient Greek), which flows into the Araxes. Pliny (6.10) mentions the Cyrus river, as well as the Araxes.
A capital city of the Sogdian Region. Possibly modern-day city of Khujand, Tajikistan.

Accompanied by a gold triangle. This is an alternative reading for Miller's (vol.3, 40) c. Carras. Orosius mentions two cities in this area: Carris (1.2.42) and Carras (1.2.41), stating: a Carris civitate usque ad oppidum Catippi, inter Hyrcanos et Batrianos, mons Menalius... [Mount Menalius is [located in the area] between the city of Carris up until the fortified town of Catippi, between the Hyrcanos and Batrianos.]. Orosius also states: a fonte Tigridis usque ad Carras civitatem inter Massagetas et Parthos, mons Ariobarzanes. [Mount Ariobbarzanes is [located in the area] between the source of the Tigris up until the city of Carras, between the Massagetas and the Parthos.]

Alternatively, the Expositio Mappe Mundi describes the area behind Alexander's Wall in detail (also attested in the Hereford Map: see Omnia horribilia), noting that, [Here are exceedingly savage people, eating human flesh and drinking blood (humanis carnibus uescentes), the evil sons of Cain.] It may be that Ciuitas Carnis is a conflation or confusion of the Expositio Mappa Mundi and Orosian traditions.

This toponym turns up in slightly altered forms on the Ebstorf and Hereford maps as Ottorogorra and Octoricirus, respectively. Orosius describes it as a river (1.2.13). Hugh of Saint-Victor describes it as a city, which takes it name from the river (Gautier Dalché, p. 143, l. 290). The Hereford analogue notes it as a city only.

Miller (vol. 3, 39) suggests that Coro Regio refers to Aethicus Ister's Chormarces. Ister writes: Umerosi Chormarces capessunt Olchis Murrenos clemaxo umbri. [The Humar Mountains and the Chormarcian [Mountain Range] hold the Olches and the Murini in the peak of gloom.] (Herren, VI.59.110-112)

The Hereford map shows a Rengnum Craphis in the same geographical location. Alternatively, if this inscription literally meant the region of Chorus, it could possibly be referring to the region of the Northwest Wind, Ventus Chorus, although its geographical location would be incorrect.

Miller (vol. 3, 40) transcribes this as Sima, with an -a over the -i, suggesting it might be read Sraima or Srauna. The reading of this inscription, however, remains unclear. It appears to begin with an s-, followed by an -i or -r, with an abbreviated -a either before or after the second letter. Thus it could also be read Sarina or Sairna. It may refer to Orosius, who notes (1.1.13): ubi flumen Chrysorhoas et promunturium Samara orientali excipiuntur oceano. [where the River Chrysorhoas and the promontory Samara meet the eastern ocean.]

The intention was clearly to write the inscription between the two rivers, but the scribe soon realized that there was not enough room and the final -a is written across the second river.

The ink used in this inscription is darker than others nearby, e.g. Regio Coro.

J. Richard notes that Lambert de Saint-Omer places Lazorum gens in the same geographical location as Iazaron. (Richard, p. 229, fn. 3) Miller (vol. 3, 40) also notes Lazorum gens in Lambert de Saint-Omer's World Map (Miller, vol. 3, 48). Chekin (230) suggests that Iazaron is a corruption of the Khazars or Khaaria, i.e. Gazara.

Analogues for Ebstorf (Lazorum gens) and the Psalter List map: In India est civitates ... Thazaron, Sagasta. [In India are the cities of ... Thazaron, Sagasta].

Alternatively, Iazeron may be very corrupt references to Theron, described as a city on the island of Taprobane (modern-day Sri Lanka). See Pinder and Parthay's Ravennatis Anonymi Cosmographia et Guidonis Geographica (419). Etheron, a variant spelling of Theron, is further discussed in Jordanes (5-6).

Mount Oscobares is modern-day Mount Kaliash. Orosius (1.2.43) notes the spelling as Oscobares, as does the Ebstorf analogue. Oriosus: ab oppido Cathippi usque ad vicum Safri inter Dahas Sacaraucas et Parthyenas mons Oscobares, ubi Ganges fluuius oritur. [from the fortified city of Cathappi up until the city of Safri, between the Dahas Sacaraucas and Parthyenas, [is located] Mount Oscobares, where the Ganges river springs forth.] The substitution of an r for an s and vice versa (here in the position of the second letter) is not unusual.

Alternatively, Solinus (Collectanea Rerum Memorabilium, 37.1) mentions: sub radicibus montis [at the foot of a mountain] quem Catoten accolae nominant, Scythis proximo... [which the local people call Catoten, near Scythia.]

The -lF following Ganges is likely inverted and means Fl-. Given the medial point between the two words, they appear to be of the same inscription.

The surprising inclusion of the Ganges as a fifth river of Paradise may derive from Isidore of Seville's popular and influential Etymologies, where he states:

"The Ganges is the river that the Sacred Scriptures call Phison, going out from Paradise and continuing on to the regions of India. And it is called Phison, that is, 'throng,' because it is filled with ten great tributaries and is made into one. It is called Ganges from Gangarus, the king of India. This river is said to rise up in the manner of the Nile and burst out over the lands of the Orient." [Isidore of Seville, The Etymologies of Isidore of Seville, trans. S. A. Barney, W. J. Lewis, J. A. Beach, O. Berghof (Cambridge, 2006), XIII.xxi.8, 280.]
One of the rivers which flows from Paradise.
One of two: this one flows from Paradise. Euphrates 2 lies to the west of this inscription, flowing North to South.
One of the rivers which flows from Paradise.
One of the rivers which flows from Paradise.
From the Tale of the Trees of the Sun and Moon in the Alexander Romance, where Alexander sought answers from the trees.
The final -e of lune is obscured. From the Tale of the Trees of the Sun and Moon in the Alexander Romance, where Alexander sought answers from the trees.
Aethicus Ister (Basel 1575, p. 5) and Hugh of Saint-Victor (Gautier Dalché, p. 142, l. 252) note a city in the east named Nisibi.
Altars of the Free and the Pillars of Hercules
Associated with a golden icon denoting a location along the Phison River.
There is also a Civitas Peliopolis, identified here as Andrianopolis, just below this inscription.
The inscription is outlined by a surrounding box, maybe to highlight its status as a region rather than a city or river. This is not, however, common across the map.

Ambiguous identification: one option is modern-day Erzurum in Turkey, the other Ra's al-'Ayn in Syria. Either is plausible, given their locations and connections to the Byzantine emperor Theodosius I.

Additionally, it should be noted that given the location of this inscription, just north of Civitas Elam; Theodosopolis may be referring to Thesia (Psalter List Map) and its possible corruptions.
One of two; Euphrates 1 is just to the east, flowing from Paradise.

Miller (vol. 3, 41) suggests that the Peliopolis here might refer to a Heliopolis analogue on the Ebstorf map, but Heliopolis is already on the Psalter Map if one concurs that Oliopolim is Heliopolis. Hugh of Saint-Victor notes (Gautier Dalché, 141-142): "In Media civitas Persipolis. In Sabea regione civitas Siraph et Adrianopolis.” [In Media, the city of Persepolis. In the region of Saba, the city of Siraph and Adrianopolis.]

There is also a Pesiopolis just above this inscription, translated as Persepolis.

Inscription written just east of a body of water containing one or two fish. The figure of sfish included in this lake is likely a reference to either or both of the miracles of catching fish in the Sea of Gailiee attributed to Jesus in the Gospels (see Luke 5:1–11 and John 21:1–14).
Antiochia written c. antio with -chia as superscript.
This inscription likely refers to the city on the Sea of Galilee, since Stannum Genesar, just above, refers to the sea itself.
This is likely the analogue on the Hereford Map, the Fluuius torrens Cison, or the Rushing Qishon/Kishon River.
M(ons) Excelsus ubi deabolus statuit d(omi)n(u)m
High mountain where the devil tempted the lord.

The image of a mountain is adjacent. From Matthew 4:8-10: Iterum assumpsit eum diabolus in montem excelsum valde: et ostendit ei omnia regna mundi, et gloriam eorum, et dixit ei: Hæc omnia tibi dabo, si cadens adoraveris me. Tunc dicit ei Jesus: Vade Satana: Scriptum est enim: Dominum Deum tuum adorabis, et illi soli servies. King James Version: [Again, the devil taketh him up into an exceeding high mountain, and sheweth him all the kingdoms of the world, and the glory of them; and saith unto him, all these things will I give thee, if thou wilt fall down and worship me. Then saith Jesus unto him, Get thee hence, Satan: for it is written, thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.]
Inscription located just East of the source of the Nile, depicted as a rock from which water flows.
Perhaps a reference to the mythical Nile Lake considered the source of the Nile.
This inscription likely refers to the Monastery of Saint Paul the Anchorite, located in Egypt's eastern desert. Associated with a gold triangle with a cross at the top.

Accompanied by a gold triangle. Miller (vol. 3, 41) notes that the Ebstorf map contains an analog, Salitrix. Hugh of Saint-Victor's (Gautier Dalché, 69 and 149) mentions: Saline ibi sunt... [Here are Saline...] and compares this to Orosius (1.2.78): usque ad lacum Salinarum. [Up to the Salinarum lake]. Neither, however, is noted as a city.
This toponym, also in a number of other mappaemundi, refers to the modern-day city of Cairo in Egypt. It should not be confused with the city of Babylon in the Middle East.
The Barns of Joseph, noted in the Old Testament, were the common medieval identification of the great Pyramids of Giza. The inscription is accompanied by three golden icons.
If this inscription goes with the Orrea Iosep just above, it would suggest that two bishops were always present at the great pyramids.
Orosius (1.2.90) and Isidore (14.5.6) note Gaetula / Gaetulos.
Denoted by a large gold icon with multiple towers. Orosius (1.2.8) notes that along with Egypt, Alexandria marks the beginning of Africa.
The stroke of the quill represented as the medial point between "Provincia" and "Lexandria" may be instead a downstroke for a capital A.
The Altars of Philaeni refer to a legend that commemorates two brothers of Carthage who chose to be buried alive for their patriotism.
